body: • An interview with Marvin Rees, the newly elected mayor of Bristol, said he was the UK’s first black mayor. We should have described him as the UK’s first directly elected black mayor. Allan Glaisyer Minns, who was mayor of the Norfolk town of Thetford from 1904 to 1906, is believed to be the UK’s first black mayor (Once upon a time in the west, 23 May, page 6, G2). • An analysis piece (Why Gove’s ‘5m migrants’ claim is absurd, 23 May, page 7) said that in the event of Turkey joining the EU, “Britain’s membership of the Schengen area” would create a barrier to the movement of Turkish workers to the UK. The writer intended to say that Britain’s non-membership of the Schengen area would do so. • The name of Werner Faymann, who resigned as chancellor of Austria earlier this month, was misspelled several times as Feymann in an editorial (One leader’s fall in Vienna, and the woes of a whole continent, 11 May, page 30). • Because of an editing error, we omitted the final letter from the surname of Rabbi Harry Jacobi, a co-signatory of a letter in Friday’s paper (Give refugee children an education here, 20 May, page 32). • Other recently corrected articles include: Women-only gyms are a world away from boys’ clubs such as Muirfield
